facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1964 filed by special leave against judgment dated December 1, 1961 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 21 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 21 of 1960.

facts.text: Mohan Industries Limited incorporated on July 5, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the Company was incorporated on July 5, 1947, before the date of the agreement.

facts.text: Assessee Alapati Venkataramaiah was proprietor of Mohan Tile Works manufacturing tiles and bricks, owning factory buildings, plant and machinery.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, Alapati Venkataramaiah, was the proprietor of Mohan Tile Works, engaged in the manufacture of tiles and bricks and owned the factory buildings, plant and machinery.

facts.text: Agreement dated March 17, 1948 between assessee and Shri Manthena Venkata Raju to sell factory, plant, machinery, furniture, stocks and goodwill to Mohan Industries Limited for Rs. 2,00,000/-

anchor.surface_text: The assessee entered into an agreement dated March 17, 1948. with one Shri Manthena Venkata Raju agreeing to sell to the Mohan Industries Limited, hereinafter called the Company, the aforesaid factory, plant, machinery, furniture, stocks and goodwill for a sum of Rs. 2,00,000/-

facts.text: Assessment year 1948-49, accounting year official year 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment year in question is 1948-49 and the accounting year is the official year 1947-48.

facts.text: Assessee appointed managing agents of the company on July 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was appointed managing agents of the companypany on July 15, 1947,

facts.text: On March 11, 1948, assessee wrote letter on behalf of company to Director of Industries and Commerce, Madras, with list of assets.

anchor.surface_text: and on March 11, 1948, he wrote a letter on behalf of the companypany to the Director of Industries and Commerce. Madras, furnishing a detailed list of land, building and machinery companyprising the assets of the companypany together with their value,

facts.text: On March 20, 1948, assessee credited with Rs. 2,00,000/- in books of the company.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1948, the assessee was credited with the price of Rs.200000/- in the books of the companypany.

facts.text: Sale deed for land executed in favour of company on November 22, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, 1948, sale deed in respect of land was executed in favour of the companypany.

facts.text: On December 9, 1948, company mortgaged land, buildings, machinery etc. for Rs. 1,00,000/- to State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1948, the companypany mortgaged the land with all its buildings and structures thereon and the machinery. plant and other property for Rs. 1,00,000/- to the State of Madras.

facts.text: Board of Directors resolution No. 22 on March 16, 1949 approved agreement dated March 17, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On March 16. 1949. the Board of Directors, by resolution No. 22 approved the agreement dated March 17, 1948,

facts.text: Agreement approved at annual general meeting on April 10, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: and on April 10, 1949, the agreement was approved at the annual general meeting of the companypany.

facts.text: First annual report dated March 22, 1949 stated company registered July 5, 1947 and agreement with assessee on 17-3-1948.

anchor.surface_text: In the first annual report dated March 22, 1949, it was stated as follows The companypany was registered on 5th July 1947. ... with Sri Alapati Venkatramiah, Proprietor of Mobart Tile Works on 17-3-1948.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer assessed Rs. 79,494/- as capital gains under s. 12B for 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the assessee had returned this income as capital gains in his return and the Income Tax Officer, without any discussion, held that the assessee realised an excess of Rs.79,494/over and above the original companyt and this was capital gains assessable under s. 12B of the Act.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner claiming no complete transaction as only Rs.1 lakh received, balance pending.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and in the grounds of appeal stated that the Income Tax Officer erred in determining the excess over the original companyt in respect of the building at Rs. 79,494/- as attracting tax to capital gains. As a matter of fact the building was sold at Rs. 1,69,950, but a sum of one lakh alone was received and the balance is yet to be received.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld the assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner observed that the fact that a part of the sale amount had number been realised was irrelevant. ... I am satisfied that the sum of Rs. 79,494/- as returned by the appellant under the head capital gains was rightly included in the assessment.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal by order dated November 24, 1955 held no sale or transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal, by its order dated November 24, 1955, held that there was in fact numbersale, much less legal transfer of lands, buil dings, machinery etc., to the limited liability companypany

facts.text: Commissioner filed application under s.35, Tribunal rectified order on March 8, 1957 upholding assessment.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Commissioner of Income Tax filed an appli cation under s. 35 of the Act ... the Tribunal held that in pursuance of cl. 6 of the agr eement dated March 17, 1948, the possession of the entire factor y was immediately handed over to Mohan Industries

facts.text: High Court answered question in affirmative: Rs.79,494 assessable as capital gains.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, it answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: Asset values: Plant Machinery Rs.15,989; Furniture Rs.18,805; Electric goods Rs.1,289; Site Construction Rs.1,26,470; Stock Rs.30,050; Goodwill Rs.7,396 total Rs.2,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: Further it held that the entries in the account books of Mohan Industries under date March 20, 1948, showed that a sum of Rs. 2,00,000/- was credit ed in favour of the assessee and the asset accounts were debited as foll ows Plant Machinery -a L.P.27Rs. 15,989 0 0 Furniture account 2918,80500 Electric goods 31 1,289100 Site Construction amount331,26,47O00 Stock amount 34 30,05000 Goodwill account 407,39660 TotalUs.2,00,00000

facts.text: Supreme Court held only furniture valued at Rs.18,805 transferred before April 1, 1948; no capital gains for Rs.79,494 but only attributable to furniture.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that only one asset, namely, furniture was transferred before April 1, 1948. In the result, we answer the question referred to the High Court as follows In the facts and circumstances of the case the sum of Rs. 79,494/- is number assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49, but only such part of it, if any, as is attributable to the capital gain made by the transfer of furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- is assessable.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 21 of 1960.
This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh answering the question referred to it under s. 66 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, against the appellant.

under s. 66 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, against the appellant. The question referred to was whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case a sum of Rs. 79,494/- is assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: Turning now to the agreement dated March 17, 1948, it is urged that this is an agreement to sell and not a sale deed... It seems to us that it was a conditional agreement to sell and before it could ripen into a contract between the company and the assessee, it had to be adopted by the company.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that title to these assets could not pass to the company till the conveyance was executed and registered. See Commissioner of Income Tax v. Bhurangya Coal Co. No such conveyance was executed before April 1, 1948.

arguments.claim: Furniture title passes by delivery on March 17, 1948

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that possession of furniture was delivered on March 17, 1948, and as title to furniture can pass by delivery, capital gains, if any, accrued on that date. In the circumstances of the case, delivery must have been made with the intention of passing title.

holdings.text: Accordingly, we hold that only one asset, namely, furniture was transferred before April 1, 1948. In the result, we answer the question referred to the High Court as follows: In the facts and circumstances of the case the sum of Rs. 79,494/- is not assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49, but only such part of it, if any, as is attributable to the capital gain made by the transfer of furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- is assessable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No transfer before 1/4/1948 of immovables (no registered deed), stocks (not capital asset), goodwill (with business); only furniture by delivery; thus full Rs.79,494 not assessable under s.12B.
